body:
> Dear all, I have shared a use case in the comments sections. I hope this helps for others who are interested in this functionality My Kind Regards Francis Guchie Kirago *Skype:* francisguchie *Whatsapp: *232 79 19 44 07 *LINKEDIN:* https://www.linkedin.com/in/francis-guchie-kirago-a4379617/ twitter: @francisguchie
> […](#)
> On Mon, May 4, 2020 at 1:56 PM Rahul Pawar ***@***.***> wrote: All necessary comments have been addressed and rebased, I think it's ready to get merged. — You are receiving this because you commented. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <[#738 (comment)](https://github.com/apache/fineract/pull/738#issuecomment-623479143)>, or unsubscribe <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AFNCABXNKUIT44UQFI5M5I3RP3CPRANCNFSM4LPITBVA> .

@francisguchie  thanks for your time, would you like to volunteer for QA?
Also, there is going to be second phase of development for this feature, once we UI support.
Hello @ptuomola . Thanks for taking on this work. You forgot to change the JDK version to 11 in Travis.
Integration Tests are failing. Maybe run them locally and take time to see if you can fix them. This is valuable work. Thanks.

Seems to be very similar problems for all the test. Looks like when one is fixed..you can easily copy to the other failing tests and fix them too.

@rrpawar96 sorry to be a PITA but could I suggest you change the message of the (now single, thanks) commit from "GLIM_GSIM enhancement" to "GLIM_GSIM enhancement (FINERACT-603)"? Just do:

    git commit --amend -m "GLIM_GSIM enhancement (FINERACT-603)"
    git push --force rrpawar96

 > nikpawar89 : @vorburger I am fine with these changes, if you are satisfied we should merge this PR.

Ok, great, then I'll finally merge this one ASAP.

Re. Tomcat versions, that's totally fine IMHO. But we should document it - do you want to add just 1 bullet point about it on https://github.com/apache/fineract#requirements as part of this PR, like this:

* Java >= 1.8 (Oracle JVMs have been tested)
* Tomcat 9 (since FINERACT-730; Tomcat 7/8, now 9 *is* required)
* MySQL 5.5
@awasum OK for you to merge, or LGTM for me to self merge?

Closing this one, because both `tomcatRun` and `tomcatRunWAR` are (about to be) removed in #807.

@ptuomola

Any active committers willing to review this one?

[Mailing list replies](https://markmail.org/thread/i3dtzfks2nqslscm) engagement to be supportive and in favour of this.

I'll self merge it in 1 this week-end if no one raises any objections.
Failed due to `testInterestTransferForSavings()` and thus requires #815 ...
FINERACT-603 comment says functional verification will be performed by @francisguchie post merge.

Thanks everyone for your comments. This is still a bit WIP - I've just fixed the depreciated and unchecked warnings, as well as some other build errors. Still a few integration tests failing - will fix them next.

@nazeer1100126 I noticed your previous #823 #824, because I "watch" this repo on GitHub. FYI Yyou don't need to create N new PRs the same thing just to re-launch a Travis CI build, which is why I suspect you're doing this? Just closing and re-opening just cause a new build. Or you can add a newline and force push :smile: 

As for the test failures, please read and follow https://github.com/apache/fineract#pull-requests which we recently added, see the "New Policy about how to deal with unstable tests" thread on the Fineract Dev list.
@nazeer1100126 I've (exceptionally, we typically should not..) "self merged" this PR to unblock you in #825!

> @ptuomola Great, thanks! Small thing: Would you perhaps like to add a trivial new integration test here, doing GET /apiDocs/ asset 200 instead of 400, just to ensure future non-regression for this? Just a thought.

@vorburger Sounds good - will do this tomorrow!

@ptuomola I've run into this kind of thing before - it could be caused e.g. by Oracle Java vs. OpenJDK, which include different root certificates. Haven't investigated this particular problem, but thought I'd mention it here in case that is it.
#820 by @ptuomola is picking this up... I'll close this PR when that is merged.
@nazeer1100126 this should pass if you rebase now.
This is still work in progress - but looked like if I kept it as draft then Travis would not build it. Will let you know once I've fixed the integration tests and then it's ready for review.
It's OK, just ping any of us when you think it's ready for review.

> @ptuomola I've run into this kind of thing before - it could be caused e.g. by Oracle Java vs. OpenJDK, which include different root certificates. Haven't investigated this particular problem, but thought I'd mention it here in case that is it.

@vorburger Thanks! Found the issue: there is a bug in OpenJDK 11.0.2. They've implemented SSL connection reuse, but the reuse discards all the certificates shared during the earlier use of the connection, which results in this error. relaxedHTTPSValidation doesn't help as it still expects some certificate, and in this case there is none. 

The issue is fixed in later OpenJDK 11 builds (e.g. 11.0.7) which is what I have on my own machine, and hence I did not see this. However Travis pulls in 11.0.2 and I was not able to find an easy way to get it to use a later minor version. 

So I fixed the Travis build by getting it to use OpenJDK 12 which has this fix. I'm assuming that will still be OK, because in the Gradle file we specify JDK 11. Alternatively need to find some way to get Travis to download and install 11.0.7 instead...
@xurror @awasum I found the SSL issue (bug in OpenJDK) and all the tests now seem to pass, so this should be ready for your review.

Aside from that, this is really a good job. We might have to do something about the java version in travis.yml.
@vorburger please can you have a look at this?

Good work Petri. Thank you.

On Thu, May 7, 2020, 07:39 Petri Tuomola <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@ptuomola* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In fineract-provider/build.gradle
> <https://github.com/apache/fineract/pull/820#discussion_r421271515>:
>
> > @@ -21,6 +21,9 @@ Run as:
>  gradle clean bootRun'''
>
>  project.ext.jerseyVersion = '1.19.4'
> +ext["rest-assured.version"] = '4.3.0'
>
> Looks like it does not work for transitive dependencies - you need to
> explicitly list all the jars for which you want the version to apply. I've
> done this and listed the JARs we are currently using. But of course if we
> add some in the future then this list needs to be updated to avoid
> incompatible classes...
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/fineract/pull/820#discussion_r421271515>, or
> unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ADWPAYDTO6GKGHHCKFQCHYTRQJJQRANCNFSM4MZDAOXA>
> .
>

> I also ran this locally, though it passes, I saw some warnings which caught my attention.
> `
> 
> > Task :compileIntegrationTestJava
> > /C/Users/Kaze/Documents/src/fineract/fineract-provider/src/integrationTest/java/org/apache/fineract/integrationtests/StaffTest.java:135: warning: [unchecked] unchecked cast
> > final List responseActive = (List)StaffHelper.getStaffListWithState(requestSpec, responseSpec, "active");
> > ^
> > required: List
> > found:    Object
> > /C/Users/Kaze/Documents/src/fineract/fineract-provider/src/integrationTest/java/org/apache/fineract/integrationtests/StaffTest.java:144: warning: [unchecked] unchecked cast
> > final List responseInactive = (List)StaffHelper.getStaffListWithState(requestSpec, responseSpec, "inactive");
> > ^
> > required: List
> > found:    Object
> > 2 warnings`
> 
> Think you might want to check that. Shouldn't be a problem to fix that.

Yes - I fixed a few hundred depreciated / unchecked warnings, but looks like I missed this one. 

It's actually a bit of a funny case: in some tests, getStaffListWithState returns ArrayList<<HashMap<String, Object>> whereas in some other tests it returns LinkedHashMap. The former is in cases where it is called with expected parameters - the latter when called with invalid parameters. Given this, the obvious solution of just changing the return type from Object to something more specific doesn't really work. 

I suppose I could just get the compiler to shut up with either SuppressWarnings or with an explicit Class.cast(). Any other ideas?

> I suppose I could just get the compiler to shut up with either SuppressWarnings or with an explicit Class.cast(). Any other ideas?

I think suppressing the warning is a good idea.

@ptuomola wow, great job, nice find re. JDK!!! I'm just curious, did you notice this by comparison of Travis's VS local JDK version numbers, or do you have a link to a OpenJDK bug about this?

Using JDK 12 instead of 11 can't stay long, because even though Gradle specifies 11, that will only cause javac to allow only 11 SYNTAX, but it will still allow to build with use of 12 LIBRARIES - I've dealt with related problems in other projects, over the years. But what I think we should do due to OpenJDK bug is still do this, for now, merge, but then change it "soon". I volunteer to look into it for Travis later. Perhaps create a new JIRA dedicated to "Switch Travis from Java 12 to Java 11" (and assign it to me)?

As for javac compiler warnings, let's fix in follow up PRs. Personally I may even have left the warning instead of suppressing, as a reminder, but it really doesn't matter, ignore. 

I was also going to suggest that this could have been broken up into separate PRs first for all the code changes, while still on Java 8, and then figure out make the Java 11 build changes, but seeing your breakthrough, I'll get this in ASAP; so more of a suggestion for future smaller PRs.

Let me fully review this by staring at the diff a little longer after work today, and likely merge ASAP.

This is another major change for the project. So a mailing list message
about this will be great. Thank you all.

Many thanks @vorburger for your feedback and comments

> @ptuomola wow, great job, nice find re. JDK!!! I'm just curious, did you notice this by comparison of Travis's VS local JDK version numbers, or do you have a link to a OpenJDK bug about this?

I found it by turning on the SSL debug logging and stepping through the SSL handshakes / negotiation. But once I worked out what's going on, it was easy to find a JDK bug that someone else had raised on the same issue and that has been fixed in a later JDK minor version (https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8212885 - TLS 1.3 resumed session does not retain peer certificate chain)
 
> Using JDK 12 instead of 11 can't stay long, because even though Gradle specifies 11, that will only cause javac to allow only 11 SYNTAX, but it will still allow to build with use of 12 LIBRARIES - I've dealt with related problems in other projects, over the years. But what I think we should do due to OpenJDK bug is still do this, for now, merge, but then change it "soon". I volunteer to look into it for Travis later. Perhaps create a new JIRA dedicated to "Switch Travis from Java 12 to Java 11" (and assign it to me)?

That makes sense. There are some possible ways suggested on how to get a specific version of OpenJDK on different sites - e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29636754/can-you-specify-minor-jdk-version-for-travis-ci. However none of them seemed particularly "clean". 

I also considered upgrading the whole Linux distro being used by Travis to a newer version (probably a good idea anyway). But unfortunately the newer distro version still uses the same script to pull OpenJDK, and hence seemed to end up with the same JDK version. 

> As for javac compiler warnings, let's fix in follow up PRs. Personally I may even have left the warning instead of suppressing, as a reminder, but it really doesn't matter, ignore.

I've left this for now. 

> I was also going to suggest that this could have been broken up into separate PRs first for all the code changes, while still on Java 8, and then figure out make the Java 11 build changes, but seeing your breakthrough, I'll get this in ASAP; so more of a suggestion for future smaller PRs.

Thanks for the suggestion - will in the future submit smaller PRs. There are still a couple of cleanups I think would make sense - e.g. there's still a depreciation warning from Gradle, and some of the Gradle plugins are not at their latest versions - but I can submit those as separate PRs. 

Thanks again
FINERACT-937 created re Java 12 -> 11 on Travis.

@nemux Thank You for this!! I'm ecstatic to see interest in (my) good old MariaDB4j... :smiling_face_with_three_hearts:  But I think it's fair to say that maintaining the originally copy/pasted `dev-dependencies.gradle` has been a paint point for this project, over time. To illustrate the point I'm making, note that this will already break with #829 from @ptuomola ... I was wondering whether perhaps I could motivate you to use the opportunity of this PR to do what I just wrote up in FINERACT-939, and (finally!) just completely ditch `dev-dependencies.gradle`  here?

As the build passes here, I've merged this, in order to get ride of Xerces. I have however "mixed feelings" about the introduction of CyberNeko NekoHTML, and propose that we follow-up on that, in FINERACT-938.
@ptuomola would this LGTY (look good to you) ?
@Anh3h Just adding you to review this PR as you also worked on the Notification module. You may have a better view than me.
@ptuomola @awasum @percyashu makes sense?
Please don't merge this one just yet; I want to do some more local tests to compare this VS #812.
Please don't merge this one just yet; I want to do some more local tests to compare this VS #813.
@vorburger LGTM

@awasum was the explanation above helpful for you to merge this one?

I'll self merge it let's on Sunday (day after tomorrow, 1 week) if I don't hear back, hope fair.

LGTM.

Manthan

> @ptuomola would this LGTY (look good to you) ?

Looks good to me...
@ptuomola OK for you? @awasum @xurror no objections presumably?
@vorburger definitely makes sense... and not sure why I had left so much whitespace at the end of those lines! Probably need to configure vim to show whitespace.

@vorburger Definitely great if we can get rid of Mockrunner with its awful dependency tree. What I can't comment on is the value of this test - was it testing anything useful - and whether we had plans to build more tests like it?

> value of this test - was it testing anything useful 

Just from looking at it, I don't see this `SenderTest` doing anything particularly useful. It doesn't `assert` on anything. I doubt this adds any real value in testing Fineract's JMS support; e.g. I don't think this test would reliably catch any possible regressions in Fineract's JMS support. (Which isn't exactly it's top most used feature anyway, as far as I know.)

> and whether we had plans to build more tests like it?

according to [git log history](https://github.com/apache/fineract/commits/develop/fineract-provider/src/test/java/org/apache/fineract/notification/SenderTest.java), it was written 3 years ago, by @adhyans ... Adhyan, if you are still alive and have any interest in Fineract, would be interested to chime in here and let us know if you can still sleep well at night :smile: if we delete this `SenderTest`? It's dependency on `mockrunner-jms` was giving us a hard time (see FINERACT-846 and FINERACT-938), and we don't' see much value in that particular test anymore, compared to the dependency management headache its use of `mockrunner-jms` (which is, at least now, only used in that test), and we'd like to remove it. Do you have any strong objections?
Anyone reading, chime in on FINERACT-944 for a more general discussion re. the Notifications feature.

I'll rebase and "self merge" this one, exceptionally without LGTM approvals from others, because this is more of an infrastructure related than a Fineract Java code change. It's also security related, and I don't see why anyone would object to this, so I'll just go ahead..

Seems another Integration Test is Flaky?

I am sorry...I forget about this because I saw your reply on mobile but never returned to merge this. Your explanation was good enough and I dont have any more questions. We can merge this now. Sorry for delay.

The IT failure here is FixedDepositTest > testFixedDepositAccountClosureTypeWithdrawal_WITH_HOLD_TAX - I've just created FINERACT-950 and raised #843.

Looks great to me
@awasum merge if this LGTY? And then close FINERACT-926 - with this, it's fully done.
This failed due to FINERACT-855, which #848 ignores - unrelated to Gradle upgrade.
exceptionally self merged totally trivial code clean up change which passed the build
This is now ready, BUT we first (and separately) need FINERACT-951 ...
@awasum @xurror @ptuomola this fully passed the build now, and I've assumed no objections to self merging this.
@xurror @awasum @ptuomola agreed?
Oh wait, integrationTest needs those.. but shouldn't there be a separate scope for that then?
Sounds interesting... Let me check that to see what can I do

@maektwain thanks for reminding me of Awaitility! I had actually used it in a past life, but kind of forgotten about it, and I guess re-created something like it here... :smile: Let me propose to introduce it in a simpler case in #851, and then use it here as well.
@maektwain does this LGTY? Anyone else interested in reviewing this?
Fine with me
@ptuomola @xurror @awasum OK for you?
@xurror makes sense, right? LGTY and OK to merge?

Hi

The reason why I added this was because some of the Gradle plugins (spotbugs etc?) were compiled against 1.8, whereas the default version being pulled in by gradle was an older one (1.7). This resulted in errors in the gradle log. 

However you've now removed the explicit version, but I don't see the errors reappearing. So I'm assuming some other dependency change has fixed this. In which case of course no issue in changing back to default versions...
Looks great to me
@ptuomola how do you like this?
I think is a good and simple fix.
Ping.. Whats left here maybe just the integration test otherwise everything looks great.
Yeah I just reviewed this.  Looks good to me.  I reviewed it seems solid to me.

> I think is a good and simple fix.

OK, thanks. I've "self-merged" this based on this review comment (and thumbs up from @trackcc).

If anyone else reading this understands this better and thinks this is the wrong fix (is this just addressing a "symptom" rather the real "root cause"?), then please (comment on to) re-open FINERACT-957 and let's discuss further there.
Anyone willing to review this one? @nemux @awasum @xurror @ptuomola @trackcc LGTY?
@ptuomola does this LGTY? @awasum et al no I'm sure objections to this?

> Yeah I just reviewed this. Looks good to me. I reviewed it seems solid to me.

Thanks! I've self merged based on this. Feel free to help with more code reviews... :smile: appreciate it.

I expect this PR will fail to fully pass integration tests, because it will highlight the problem described in FINERACT-958. Not having the time to deal with FINERACT-958 myself, I'm slightly torn how to proceed here... temporarily slapping an `@Ignore` on the (new) entire `testTriggeringManualExecutionOfAllSchedulerJobs()` seems like such a shame.
